Cardiff Carnival 25th Anniversary Project interviewer Steve Fletcher.
The location of the interview is the Swicker office.
Today's date is the 13th of October 2015 and with me I have Sarah and Ren.
Ren would you be kind enough to go first and spell your name in full for the record?
I'm Ren Hubbock-Mellie, so that's R-E-N-N-N-N-H-U-B-B-U-C-K-M-E-L-L-Y.
Lovely. Sarah would you do the same please?
I'm Sarah Annoil, which is spelled S-A-R-A-A-N-N-W-Y-L.
Lovely and we're off. So the carnival just gone, Cardiff Carnival 2015.
How and in what way did you lovely people take part?
Well, we were participating in glorious fashion by puppeteering a giant blue bald naked fertility goddess
down through the streets of Cardiff, which is an awesome experience.
A really hard physical work and just really, really sort of celebratory and fun as well as quite adversarial at times.
Of course, the vision and the author of the work was Nicky Fogarty.
What were her influences when she made this piece?
I remember she said some photographs with me way before she ever bent a willow cane and covered it with anything.
I think the whole idea grew and grew and grew until it became enormous and became much bigger than she expected.
That's true.
She was looking into pre-Columbian fertility goddess ideas basically around feminine empowerment and feminine sexuality.
But accessing a whole load of sort of contemporary and sort of 70s feminist ideas about the female radical sort of sexual power.
I remember her showing me a picture of a sort of a pre-Columbian fertility goddess and we both agreed that,
yeah, she's all bum, belly and bust. That's what she's going to be.
Nicky was saying that.
So Nicky's inside this backpack and she's in a sense coming down.
She's an extension of the spine of this giant blue woman who's got to be at least three meters high, if not higher.
And I'm right in thinking that she's in a, we can name it, why not, we're advertising a Tesco trolley too.
And that she has two hands which can be operated as well and they're on bamboo sticks.
And this is where you both come in. Is that right?
Yeah.
Yes. So what was it like operating that?
What was it? Because it seems to be quite a powerful statement to be parading a giant,
naked blue woman through the streets of Cardiff in 2015.
Exactly the kind of statement I personally approve of.
How did the audience react or not, as the case may be?
Well, there was lots of different kind of reactions.
The older women were cheering as soon as they saw it.
Yeah, because there's also not just that this beautiful blue woman,
there's also these quotes that she put on, such as we are people, not things.
She took, I think, from the internet or other places.
So they were all over.
And I think people are also quite confused by what it was.
They weren't entirely sure how to take it.
So the men, a lot of them were just sort of quite quiet and didn't really know how to react.
It was quite interesting that because it wasn't sexy, but it was naked.
She had a big belly, big boobs, big bums.
People were initially like, my god's big naked lady.
And then they were like, well, there's something more being said here.
So that was just, there was not confusion, but an interesting sort of it was the biggest impact,
I think, of that particular carnival.
The biggest.
Yes, it was the biggest single visual statement.
Yeah, yeah, absolutely.

Excellent.

which is why the sculpture was blue and had stars.
